Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Beta-catenin Regulation during Asymmetric Stem Cell Divisions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how a single-celled zygote (the fertilized egg) develops into a multicellular animal with diverse, interconnected and properly-specified tissues is core to our understanding of how animals, including humans, actually work. One of the great discovery tools in developmental biology is the small nematode, Caenorhabditis elegans. Taking advantage of the available genetic tools in this organism, the large international community of C. elegans biologists, has made great strides in explaining the cellular and developmental mechanisms that govern how all animals function. For instance, it is now known that the same cell communication pathways control the development of diverse species, including C. elegans, and mammals like mice and humans. This collaborative project investigates the role of one of these conserved pathways in C. elegans development, focusing on asymmetric stem cell divisions. It will extend these studies to the most well-established mammalian example of a stem cell population, intestinal stem cells. In this way, it will determine the extent to which existing models of control of C. elegans stem cell divisions are conserved in mammals. Thus the research will provide a strong framework to address common problems that stem cells in these distantly-related animals encounter. The project will broaden the impact of these studies by 1) increasing public engagement and science literacy through hands-on workshops geared toward the general public, 2) recruiting the next generation of STEM scientists by bringing 8th graders from rural Iowa communities with large Hispanic populations to campus for a day of career simulations and 3) retaining current STEM undergraduates by extending undergraduate research opportunities, including to disadvantaged and underrepresented groups.


Asymmetric cell division (ACD) drives cell fate specification in animals from mammals to nematodes. Stem cells in these organisms use ACD to generate a differentiated daughter and a new stem cell. Wnt signaling is a conserved regulator of ACD and cell fate through its control of the transcriptional activator beta-catenin. The goal of this project is to elucidate the mechanisms of beta-catenin regulation during asymmetric stem cell divisions by analyzing regulation of the C. elegans beta-catenin, SYS-1, and to begin testing the resulting mechanisms in mammals. C. elegans is well-suited for these analyses because of its genetic and molecular tools, in vivo ACD imaging, the separation of the signaling and adhesion functions of beta-catenin into distinct genes and because of recent findings that SYS-1 is negatively regulated by homologs of the beta-catenin destruction complex: Axin, APC and CK1alpha. The mammalian intestinal crypt, arguably the best-known example of Wnt-controlled stem cell maintenance, will be used to test conservation of SYS 1 regulatory mechanisms and will also inform the worm models. This project will determine the mechanism by which Axin localizes the destruction complex, and the extent to which destruction complex regulation of beta-catenin in the nucleus is conserved. The results of these studies are predicted to provide broadly important insight into developmental cell fate specification and the role of Wnt pathway-induced ACD in tissue homeostasis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout development and even in adulthood, many of an organism's cells multiply by growing in size, copying their genetic information (chromosomes) and then splitting into two "daughter" cells.  The major focus of the Neufeld research program is a protein named APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) which functions to keep cell growth and division under control. In mammals such as humans and mice, APC is particularly crucial for regulation of the adult colon, where over 10 billion new cells are made each day. The human colon is lined with a single layer of specialized cells that perform the critical functions of this organ.  Some of these cells secrete mucin, which lubricates the colon, while others serve to absorb water from the waste material that passes through. Other cells, called stem cells, are responsible for dividing in a highly controlled manner to replace the specialized cells after they have lived for approximately six days.  Neufeld proposes that this stem cell division is asymmetric, resulting in production of two, non-identical daughter cells: one which resembles the parent stem cell, and the other which is a more specialized "worker" cell that carries out the necessary activities of the colon.  Precise control of stem cell division must be maintained to insure that the colon has the optimum number of stem cells and "worker" cells, a state of balance called homeostasis. 

The Neufeld laboratory has tested whether APC is involved in regulating asymmetric cell division in the mouse colon. Our results suggest that mice defective in APC are compromised for asymmetric cell division in their colons.  Further, these same mice appear to have fewer stem cells, a predicted consequence of altered cell symmetry. Colon stem cells require continued exposure to a specific small protein which serves as a signal instructing them to divide. This small protein signal, called Wnt, interacts with other proteins on the cell surface to initiate signal transduction.  An important question remains in the field: how is this signal relayed from the cell's surface, through the cytoplasm and into the nucleus where it can trigger production of RNAs that can ultimately lead to cell division. To delve into the mechanism underlying the results from our studies of mouse colon, we used human colon cells derived from cancer and normal tissue.  Because these cells can be maintained in petri dishes and are relatively easy to manipulate, they provide a good model to test roles of specific signaling pathways in regulating cell symmetry. In our studies, we added the Wnt signaling molecule to the cells and then looked to see if Wnt signaling effected the distribution of different components of the Wnt signaling pathway. We found that cells from both cancerous and normal colon tissue showed a redistribution of Wnt signaling pathway components toward the Wnt protein on the cell surface.  Furthermore, this redistribution required APC protein. Together these results reveal a novel role for APC in control of asymmetric cell division and stem cell numbers in the mammalian colon and implicate APC in the early steps of Wnt signal transmission. In terms of broader impact, both Neufeld and graduate student Parker have given presentations to the general public focused on the basic cellular biology underlying cancer and how research with model organisms increases understanding of this complex topic. These efforts have increased science literacy and public engagement.
